description.en: This course provides an overview of the definitions, concepts, and theories of governance and explores the emergence of new governance arrangements in relation to the traditional public administration (TPA) and New Public Management (NPM) in the operation of public sectors around the world. The course focuses on the implications of governance on public policy-making and service delivery and includes case discussions of the issues and challenges of various instruments of public action for effectiveness and democratic accountability.
description.et: Kursus teeb ülevaate nn. "uue valitsemise" (new public governance) paradigmast kaasaja demokraatlike ühiskondade valitsemises ning vaatleb selle esilekerkimist võrdlevas perspektiivis traditsioonilise avaliku halduse ja uue haldusjuhtimise mudelitega. Kursuse fookus on suunatud nn. "valitsemise" (governance) perspektiivi tagajärgede uurimisele halduspoliitikate kujundamisel ja elluviimisel. Lisaks loengutele vaadeldakse juhtumianalüüside käigus erinevate nn. "valitsemise" instrumentide kasutusvõimalusi ning nende mõju halduspoliitikate tulemuslikkusele ning demokraatlikule aruandlusele.

objectives.en: This is a course about public governance that introduces students to governance in public administration and public policy. In this course, students learn about the new approaches to solving public problems in the rapidly changing context of managing public affairs where the achievement of public purposes is increasingly dependent on the interactions between the state, market, and civil society actors in self-organizing inter-organizational governance arenas.
objectives.et: Kaasaja valitsemine on magistritaseme kursus, mis annab ülevaate avaliku sektori tomimises toimunud arengutest kaasaja demokraatlikes ühiskondades. Kursus keskendub nn. "valitsemise (governance) paradigma esilekerkimisele ning halduspoliitikate kujundamisele ja elluviimisele keskkonnas, kus avalike probleemidele lahendamine sõltub järjest enam riigi, erasektori ja kodanikeühenduste omavahelisest koostööst.

learning_outcomes.en: Upon completion of this course, the students will be able to:
1) comprehend the evolution of the modes of public action in the operation of public sectors that have led to the emergence of new public governance;
learning_outcomes.et: 1) omavad ülevaadet avaliku halduse arenguperspektiividest, mis on viinud nn. "valitsetuse" (governance) paradigma esilekerkimiseni;

learning_outcomes.en: 2) be able to explain the meanings of the major concepts of governance;
3) identify and assess the principles, practices, and instruments of public action in the age of governance;
learning_outcomes.et: 3) oskavad hinnata "valitsetuse" paradigmaga seotud halduspoliitika instrumente ning tunnevad nende kasutamise võimalusi ja piiranguid;

learning_outcomes.en: 4) be able to critically analyze and evaluate the impact of various forms of governance on policy effectiveness and democracy;
learning_outcomes.et: 4) oskavad kriitiliselt hinnata "valitsetuse" instrumentide mõju valitsemise efektiivsusele ja demokraatlikule aruandlusele;

learning_outcomes.en: 5) master the basic skills of desiging, writing, and presenting a comparative analysis on the governance of a chosen issue.
learning_outcomes.et: 5) on võimelised kavandama, läbi viima ja suuliselt ette kandma võrdleva analüüsi "valitsetuse" teemal.

independent_work.et: (1) Weekly tasks. Students are expected to complete the required reading prior to class and post their weekly tasks to the course website on Moodle 24 h before class. Weekly task assignments should carefully follow the instructions provided in the course schedule below. Each task is different and may involve application of the required reading for the analysis of a real-life phenomenon, independent desk-research with various sources, analysis of policy papers etc. Each week students should be prepared to share their responses and contribute to the discussion during the seminar. (2) Case analysis. Each student will be responsible for completing a case analysis associated with the topics covered during the course. Students will sign up for cases during the first week of class. The assignment involves submitting a written paper with your case analysis (3-4 pages, single-spaced, 12 pt Times New Roman) 24 h before the session and presenting the case in class. For more detailed requirements see the assignment sheet attached to the course syllabus. (3) Comparative analysis assignment. This course includes a comparative analysis assignment that develops students' writing skills, and helps draw connections between the theoretical knowledge acquired in the course and the real world of governing societal problems. For this assignment, you will choose a public governance arrangement of interest to you and compare its application across at least two sites of rule. For more detailed requirements on how to complete this component of the course and deadlines see the assignment sheet attached to the course syllabus.

description.et: Weekly tasks (40%). Submitted each week 24h before class to Moodle. Requirements and grading criteria are outlined in the syllabus (see Moodle).

Case analysis (20%). Submitted and presented by each student during the session devoted to the chosen topic. Requirements and grading criteria are outlined in the assignment sheet attached to the syllabus (see Moodle).
Comparative analysis report and presentation (40%). Requirements and grading criteria are outlined in the assignment sheet attached to the syllabus (see Moodle).

grade_preconditions.et: Completion of all elements of the course.

grade_evaluation.et:
Students will be evaluated on the basis of (1) weekly tasks, (2) case analysis, and (3) comparative analysis assignment. Detailed description of each task is provided in Moodle. The grading scale will be the following:

100-91 points A 
90-81 points B 
80-71 points C 
70-61 points D
60-51 points E 
50-0 points F

debt_elimination.et: Detailed requirements for each individual assignment are outlined in the course syllabus (see Moodle). Late submissions will be accepted only in exceptional circumstances upon agreement with the instructor.

description.et: Session 1: Introduction to the course NB! Course syllabus and all reading materials are posted to Moodle! The first class of the semester will introduce students to the topics and requirements of the course. We will review the basics of making and managing public policy, and recall the necessary material covered in undergraduate courses. Special attention will be paid to exploring the changing context of public policy and the implications involved for designing and implementing public action. We will lay out a roadmap for the exploration of public governance in the sessions to come.

Session 2: The concept of governance - an interdisciplinary view Second week of the course will be devoted to exploring the concept of 'governance' in the sub-fields of political science and related disciplines. We will discuss the similarities and differences between various definitions and explore the utility of the concept. Also, we will try to find a common ground between the various approaches by turning to the theory of (new-)institutionalism.

Session 3: Governance in public administration and public policy In the third session, we will turn our attention to the notion of governance in public administration and public policy. We will discuss the reasons for the emergence of the governance perspective, and the rise of the 'post-bureaucratic' paradigm in public administration. You will learn how the modern state was transformed as the result of several waves of public sector reform in the late 20th century. You will understand how the subsequent changes in the structures and processes of governing have shaped the environment of public policy leading to an expanded policy domain that reaches beyond the traditional public bureaucracy.

Session 4: Modes of governance: hierarchies, markets, and networks I As the result of the succession of public sector reforms, and the changing context of public policy, we can differentiate between at least three modes of orchestrating collective action that characterize the governing processes of contemporary societies: hierarchies, markets, and networks. We will explore the manifestation of these governing styles through case analyses from across the public sectors around the world. Students are encouraged to think about the changing mix of governance styles in the making and managing of public policy of their interest.

Session 5: Modes of governance: hierarchies, markets, and networks II In the fifth session we will discuss what policy-making and implementation is like in a network society where policy develops in complex networks of governmental and nongovernmental actors. We will focus on how policy is made and managed in these inter-organizational, multi-stakeholder settings, and examine the implications for solving public problems. Further, we will ask what is the role of modern states in contemporary governance processes (are they really being 'hollowed out'?), and what is the states' capacity to steer society in the era of markets and networks.

Session 6: Presentations of comparative analysis proposals This week we will hear students' presentations of their proposals for comparative analysis of governance (for more detailed requirements see the assignment sheet in the appendix of the syllabus). Be prepared to discuss and provide feedback to a student paper assigned to you.

Session 7: Tools of governance What does governance imply for policy implementation? This week we will focus on the technology of public action, and discuss the changing mix of policy tools used for putting policies into effect. We will explore the features and characteristics of policy instruments applied in the age of governance. We will also try to determine whether governments have undergone a shift in their choice of methods for public intervention, and if so, what are the implications for various stakeholders involved in the policy process?

Session 8: Governance and democracy In this class we will examine the implications of the emergence of governance for democracy. We will discuss the challenges of governance to democracy, policy legitimacy, and accountability by posing the following questions: What are the democratic effects of governance? Do new arrangements of public action advance democracy or, on the contrary, pose problems for embedding public decisions in popular sovereignty? Does governance require a re-conceptualization of democracy? What are the mechanisms of participative governance that could be used for those purposes?

Session 9: Comparative analysis progress review This week we will review students' progress on the comparative analysis assignment. Students will make an appointment with the instructor for individual meetings devoted to discussing the development of their research projects. You will be expected to demonstrate how you have developed your project based on the feedback you received during the proposal defense. You will also receive additional consultation on how to complete your course paper.

Session 10: 'Good governance' and institutional reform in development This week's session will be devoted to exploring 'good governance' in international development and its implications for public sector institutional reform in developing and transition countries. We will explore the public sector reform strategies of various agents of development aid, and evaluate the content and implications of their models and menus of institutional reform. We will also ask what could be the alternatives to the prevailing agenda of 'good governance' and how the currently prevailing orthodox model of institutional reform could be redefined.

Session 11: Transnational governance In this session we will focus our attention to global governance as a perspective on contemporary world politics. We will explore the actors and arenas of transnational governance and familiarize ourselves with the new institutional forms of collective rule making and service delivery.

Session 12: Governance and areas of limited statehood In this session we will explore a burgeoning stream of scholarship on governance in the areas of limited statehood (ALS). We will try to make sense of the variety of state and non-state governors and distinct modes of governance in the internationalized sites of rule in the Global South. Students will explore implications for normative political theory and policy of external actors.
Session 13: Independent work on comparative analysis papers There is no class this week. Please work on your comparative analysis assignment and prepare for the presentations the following week.
Session 14: Presentation of comparative analyses I (NB! Need to pre-register for a time slot!) First set of presentations: Students present their comparative analyses to the rest of the class.
Session 15: Presentation of comparative analyses II (NB! Need to pre-register for a time slot!) Second set of presentations: Students present their comparative analyses to the rest of the class.

Session 16: Critique of governance and course wrap-up In the final session we will sum up the course by looking at the ways in which the governance theory has been critiqued, highlight the unresolved issues, and outline a future research agenda for the students of governance and public policy.
